title: Basic Identification and Visualisation of Outliers
text: First, ’re going load package create outliers ‘mtcars’ dataset. Two continuous variables (one NA´s), one logical one factor level.
code: library(outlieR)  set.seed(123) mtcars["var_1"] <- c(rnorm(29), -100, 100, NA) set.seed(234) mtcars["var_2"] <- c(-50, 32, rnorm(30)) mtcars["var_3"] <- c(rep(TRUE, 31), FALSE) mtcars["var_4"] <- factor(rep(LETTERS[1:5], times = c(10, 5, 15, 1, 1)))  # For better printing. mtcars <- tibble::as_tibble(mtcars)

title: Basic Identification and Visualisation of Outliers
text: ‘identify_outlier()’ function used identify outliers based methods parameters spesificed ‘control_outlier()’ function. control function optional use. get summary results.
code: outlier_mtcars <-   identify_outlier(mtcars,     var_1, var_2, var_3, var_4,     control = control_outlier(discrete_method = "prop", prop = 0.06, na_action = "keep")   ) print(outlier_mtcars) #> ── 5 Outliers were removed of 32 rows. ───────────────────────────────────────── summary(outlier_mtcars) #> ── 5 Outliers were removed of 32 rows. ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  #>  #> ── Summary Table of outliers ─────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #>  #> |Variable |Variable Type |Outlier Exist? | N Outliers|% Outlier | N of NAs| #> |:--------|:-------------|:--------------|----------:|:---------|--------:| #> |var_1    |dbl           |Yes            |          2|6.5 %     |        1| #> |var_2    |dbl           |Yes            |          2|6.2 %     |        0| #> |var_3    |lgl           |Yes            |          1|3.1 %     |        0| #> |var_4    |fct           |Yes            |          2|6.2 %     |        0|

title: Basic Identification and Visualisation of Outliers
text: remove rows data outliers identified previous step - call ‘filter_outlier()’ outlier object.

title: Basic Identification and Visualisation of Outliers
text: First continuous   Also multiple (combinations supported yet)   Autoplot returns ggplot, customisable ggplot2s functions.
code: # type  = "histogram" is the default identify_outlier(mtcars, var_1) |>   autoplot() identify_outlier(mtcars, var_1) |>   autoplot(type = "count") identify_outlier(mtcars, var_1, var_2) |>   autoplot(type = "hist") identify_outlier(mtcars, var_1, var_2, var_3) |>   autoplot(type = "count") identify_outlier(mtcars, var_4) |>   autoplot(type = "count") + ggplot2::ggtitle("Look E and D are Outliers")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Martinsen PS (2023). outlieR: Identify, Filter Visualisation Outliers. https://github.com/pedersebastian/outlieR, https://pedersebastian.github.io/outlieR/.

title: Control_object — control_outlier
code: control_outlier(   numeric_method = "mean_sd",   discrete_method = "prop",   threshold = NULL,   conf_int = NULL,   prop = NULL,   n_vars = NULL,   freq = NULL,   min_times = NULL,   ties_method = "min",   na_action = "keep",   ... )

title: Control_object — control_outlier
text: numeric_method dd discrete_method m threshold 'NULL' methods t-test. Default 3 mean sd method MAD method, IQD uses 2.2. conf_int conf int t-test prop proportion factors/char (0 - 1) n_vars n_vars freq f min_times m ties_method factors na_action "keep" NA default ... currently used

text: .data data.frame tibble ... variable(s) identify outlier control control_obj

title: Identity  filter — identify_outlier
code: mtcars["var_1"] <- c(rnorm(30), -100, 100) mtcars["var_2"] <- c(-50, 32, rnorm(30)) filtred <-   mtcars |> identify_outlier(var_1, var_2)  print(filtred) #> ── 4 Outliers were removed of 32 rows. ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  # ── 4 Outliers were removed of 32 rows. ──────────────────────────────────────────────────
